This fact means that a thief would not be able to turn on or use the laptop because people’s irises are unique and there is a great deal of variation between the iris from one person to the next.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most supports the company's implementing its plan to develop the prototype?
main_answers: Colored contacts allow people to change their eye color, without altering any of the other characteristics of their iris.
Insurance and security companies provide other services to companies in addition to protecting laptops.
There is considerable variation in the color and patterns present in most people's irises.
In-person security services will not suffer from technological glitches when allowing access to laptops.
others.target_option: In-person security services will not suffer from technological glitches when allowing access to laptops.

context: Nuclear fusion is a process whereby the nuclei of atoms are joined, or "fused, " and in which energy is released. One of the by-products of fusion is helium-4 gas. A recent fusion experiment was conducted using "heavy" water contained in a sealed flask. The flask was, in turn, contained in an air-filled chamber designed to eliminate extraneous vibration. After the experiment, a measurable amount of helium-4 gas was found in the air of the chamber. The experimenters cited this evidence in support of their conclusion that fusion had been achieved.
question: Why does the fact that helium-4 gas rapidly breaks down, forming ordinary helium gas after a few hours not cast doubt on the experimenters' conclusion?
answers: It is not stated whether or not a large amount of heat was released and the by-product (or one of) of fusion was measurably obtained.
Helium-4 is a by-product of fusion and so the production of other byproducts or lack thereof has no bearing on whether or not fusion was achieved within the chamber.
If the amount of helium-4 in the chamber's air was the same as ordinarily in the air outside of the chamber, it would seem to indicate no change and so no fusion achieved.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would cast doubt on the experimenters' conclusion?
main_answers: Helium-4 gas rapidly breaks down, forming ordinary helium gas after a few hours.
When fusion is achieved, it normally produces several by-products, including tritium and gamma rays.
Nuclear fusion reactions are characterized by the release of large amounts of heat.
The amount of helium-4 found in the chamber's air did not exceed the amount of helium-4 that is found in ordinary air.
others.target_option: Helium-4 gas rapidly breaks down, forming ordinary helium gas after a few hours.

context: Essayist: One of the claims of laissez-faire economics is that increasing the minimum wage reduces the total number of minimum-wage jobs available. In a recent study, however, it was found that after an increase in the minimum wage, fast-food restaurants kept on roughly the same number of minimum-wage employees as before the increase. Ttherefore, laissez-faire economics is not entirely accurate.
question: Why does the essayist's argument not depend on assuming that no study has ever found that a business has decreased the number of its minimum-wage employees after an increase in the minimum wage?
answers: The effect of the increase on unemployment nationally is unknown and doesn't change the argument
From the results of a fast food industry study, the author makes a claim for minimum-wage jobs across every industry
The author specifies "laissez-faire economics is not entirely accurate," which means some aspects are accurate
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The essayist's argument depends on assuming which one of the following?
main_answers: If laissez-faire economics makes an incorrect prediction about the minimum wage, then all the doctrines of laissez-faire economics are inaccurate.
The national unemployment rate did not increase following the increase in the minimum wage.
Minimum-wage job availability at fast-food restaurants included in the study was representative of minimum-wage job availability in general.
No study has ever found that a business has decreased the number of its minimum-wage employees after an increase in the minimum wage.
others.target_option: No study has ever found that a business has decreased the number of its minimum-wage employees after an increase in the minimum wage.

context: In Country X' s last election, the Reform Party beat its main opponent, the Conservative Party, although pollsters, employing in-person interviews shortly before the vote, had projected a Conservative Party victory. Afterwards, the pollsters determined that, unlike Conservative Party supporters, Reform Party supporters were less likely to express their party preference during in-person interviews than they were during telephone interviews. Ttherefore, using only telephone interviews instead would likely result in more accurate projections for the next election.
question: Why does the fact that in the next election, pollsters will be able to conduct more in-person interviews than telephone interviews not support the argument in the passage?
answers: In order for the party preferences of people interviewed by telephone to matter, it must be known about how many of them will actually vote.
The size of the voting base has nothing to do with the accuracy of voting projections.
What brought the projections into question to begin with was that the Conservative Party lost, so them winning would do nothing to support the argument.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following statements, if true, would most support the argument in the passage?
main_answers: For each person interviewed in telephone polls before the next election, pollsters will be able to reasonably determine the likelihood of that person voting.
In the next election, pollsters will be able to conduct more in-person interviews than telephone interviews.
The number of voters in Country X's next election will be significantly larger than the number of voters in the last election.
The Conservative Party will win the next election.
others.target_option: In the next election, pollsters will be able to conduct more in-person interviews than telephone interviews.

context: Between 1971 and 1975, the government office that monitors drug companies issued an average of 60 citations a year for serious violations of drug-promotion laws. Between 1976 and 1980, the annual average for issuance of suchs citations was only 5. This decrease indicates that the government office was, on average, considerably more lax in enforcing drug-promotion laws between 1976 and 1980 than it was between 1971 and 1975.
question: What is the basis for the argument not assuming that before 1971 the government office issued more than 60 citations a year to drug companies for serious violations of drug-promotion laws?
answers: The article did not differentiate between the types of violations but violations in general.
The drug companies still committed the violations but the number of citations dropped which shows they became lax in enforcement.
This article states that the average of 5 citations shows a lax in enforcement so it wasn't about it being only 5 citations.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The argument assumes which one of the following?
main_answers: The government office should not issue more than an average of 5 citations a year to drug companies for serious violations of drug-promotion laws.
Before 1971 the government office issued more than 60 citations a year to drug companies for serious violations of drug-promotion laws.
A change in enforcement of drug-promotion laws did not apply to minor violations.
The decrease in the number of citations was not caused by a decrease in drug companies' violations of drug-promotion laws.
others.target_option: Before 1971 the government office issued more than 60 citations a year to drug companies for serious violations of drug-promotion laws.

context: All potatoes naturally contain solanine, which is poisonous in large quantities. Domesticated potatoes contain only very small amounts of solanine, but many wild potatoes contain poisonous levels of solanine. Since most of the solanine in potatoes is concentrated in the skin, however, peeling wild potatoes makes them at least as safe to eat as unpeeled domesticated potatoes of the same size.
question: Why does the conclusion not properly follow even if it is assumed that there are no poisonous substances in domesticated potatoes other than solanine?
answers: If there amount of solanine in a peeled wild potato and an unpeeled domesticated potato of the same size, then both are equally safe to eat.
The amount of solanine in the skin has nothing to do with the amount of solanine after the wild potato is peeled.
The average size of the potato has no relevance when comparing specific potatoes of the same size.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if assumed, allows the conclusion above to be properly drawn?
main_answers: Wild potatoes are generally much smaller than domesticated potatoes.
The amount of solanine concentrated in the skin of a wild potato is large enough by itself to be poisonous.
There are no poisonous substances in domesticated potatoes other than solanine.
There is no more solanine in a peeled wild potato than in an unpeeled domesticated potato of the same size.
others.target_option: There are no poisonous substances in domesticated potatoes other than solanine.

context: Conventional wisdom suggests vaccinating elderly people first in flu season, because they are at greatest risk of dying if they contract the virus. This year's flu virus poses particular risk to elderly people and almost none at all to younger people, particularly children. Nevertheless, health professionals are recommending vaccinating children first against the virus rather than elderly people.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the fact that children are particularly unconcerned with hygiene and therefore are the group most responsible for spreading the flu virus to others provides the strongest reason for the health professionals' recommendation?
answers: If children develop immunity to other strains of the disease after catching a virus, vaccinating them would be counterintuitive.
Whether or not last year's vaccines affect this year's virus is not relevant to why a certain group of people should be first to receive this year's vaccine.

The passage explicitly states that children are at practically no risk to this year's virus, so their lack of exposure in the past would not be relevant as to why they should be getting this particular vaccine first.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, provides the strongest reason for the health professionals' recommendation?
main_answers: Children who catch one strain of the flu virus and then recover are likely to develop immunity to at least some strains with which they have not yet come in contact.
Children are particularly unconcerned with hygiene and ttherefore are the group most responsible for spreading the flu virus to others.
The vaccinations received last year will confer no immunity to this year's flu virus.
Children are no more likely than adults to have immunity to a particular flu virus if they have never lived through a previous epidemic of the same virus.
others.target_option: Children are particularly unconcerned with hygiene and ttherefore are the group most responsible for spreading the flu virus to others.

context: At many electronics retail stores, the consumer has the option of purchasing product warranties that extend beyond the manufacturer' s warranty. However, consumers are generally better off not buying extended warranties. Most problems with electronic goods occur within the period covered by the manufacturer' s warranty.
question: Explain why the fact that most of those who buy extended warranties on electronic goods do so because special circumstances make their item more likely to break than is usually the case does not strengthen the argument.
answers: An extended warranty being purchased has no bearing on when and how an item might break.
If the cost of the repairs are likely to be less than the cost of the warranty it would be more financially positive to just pay for the repair if it is needed.
Purchasing other products from a store does not effect when any one product might break.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_answers: Most of those who buy extended warranties on electronic goods do so because special circumstances make their item more likely to break than is usually the case.
Retail stores sell extended warranties in part because consumers who purchase them are likely to purchase other products from the same store.
Problems with electronic goods that occur after the manufacturer's warranty expires are generally inexpensive to fix in comparison with the cost of an extended warranty.
Some extended warranties on electronic goods cover the product for the period covered by the manufacturer's warranty as well as subsequent years.
others.target_option: Most of those who buy extended warranties on electronic goods do so because special circumstances make their item more likely to break than is usually the case.

context: Which one of the following exhibits both of the logical flaws exhibited in the argument above?
question: Why is the argument that all intelligent people are nearsighted and I am very nearsighted so I must be a genius not analogous to the argument that all chickens have beaks and this bird has a beak so this bird must be a chicken?
answers: The analogy lists both a general correlation and then states that because John has a greater degree of the one attribute then he must have a greater degree of the other.
This analogy makes an inference based negative correlation rather than a positive correlation.
This analogy makes a correlation between number of limbs and size which doesn’t contain the general analogy like in the example.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: All intelligent people are nearsighted. I am very nearsighted. So I must be a genius.
main_answers: All chickens have beaks. This bird has a beak. So this bird must be a chicken.
All pigs have four legs, but this spider has eight legs. So this spider must be twice as big as any pig.
John is extremely happy, so he must be extremely tall because all tall people are happy.
I must be stupid because all intelligent people are nearsighted and I have perfect eyesight.
others.target_option: All chickens have beaks. This bird has a beak. So this bird must be a chicken.

context: The attribution of the choral work Lacrimae to the composer Pescard (1400-1474) has been regarded as tentative, since it was based on a single treatise from the early 1500' s that named Pescard as the composer. Recently, several musical treatises from the late 1500' s have come to light, all of which name Pescard as the composer of Lacrimae. Unfortunately, these newly discovered treatises lend no support to the attribution of Lacrimae to Pescard, since __.
question: What is the reason for why the fact that there are works that can conclusively be attributed to Pescard that are not even mentioned in the treatise from the early 1500's does not logically complete the argument?
answers: if the later writings were based only on the previous one, they would not lend any new or useful evidence to support the attribution
If the original treatise was found to be questionable, the additional newer ones could still lend credence to the attribution of Lacrimae to Pescard
errors in the earlier treatise do not necessarily have any bearing on the veracity of the later findings
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the argument?
main_answers: the later treatises probably had no source for their attribution other than the earlier treatise
the author of the treatise from the early 1500's had no very strong evidence on which to base the identification of Pescard as the composer of Lacrimae
the treatise from the early 1500's misidentifies the composers of some of the musical works it considers
there are works that can conclusively be attributed to Pescard that are not even mentioned in the treatise from the early 1500's
others.target_option: there are works that can conclusively be attributed to Pescard that are not even mentioned in the treatise from the early 1500's

context: Researcher: Dinosaurs lack turbinates -- nasal cavity bone structures in warm-blooded species that minimize water loss during breathing. According to some paleobiologists, this implies that all dinosaurs were cold-blooded. These paleobiologists must be mistaken, however, for fossil records show that some dinosaur species lived in Australia and Alaska, where temperatures drop below freezing. Only warm-blooded animals could survive such temperatures.
question: Why does the claim that only warm-blooded animals could survive temperatures below freezing not serve as the argument's main conclusion?
answers: The premise regarding survival of those temperatures and the requirements of such are presented in support of the main conclusion.

The researcher is not providing a counterexample for their own argument, nor is it a counterexample for the implications of some paleo biologists. It is provided in support of the researcher's conclusion.
The researcher does not argue against or for the lack or presence of turbinates.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the researcher's argument by the claim that only warm-blooded animals could survive temperatures below freezing?
main_answers: It is presented as counterevidence to the paleobiologists' assertion that dinosaurs lack turbinates.
It is presented as a potential counterexample to the argument's main conclusion.
It is a premise offered in support of the argument's main conclusion.
It is the argument's main conclusion.
others.target_option: It is the argument's main conclusion.

context: The press reports on political campaigns these days as if they were chess games. One candidate' s campaign advisor makes a move; the other candidate' s advisor makes a countermove. The press then reports on the campaign advisors and not on the candidates. The losers in this chess game are the voters. They are deprived of the information they need to make informed decisions because the press is ignoring substantive policy issues and reporting only on the process of the campaign. It is clear that the campaign advisors should stay out of the limelight and let the press report on the most revealing positions on substantive issues the candidates have taken.
question: Why is it valid to assume that the argument in the passage depends on the assumption that the candidates in the election are taking positions on substantive policy issues?
answers: The coverage of the campaign processes is the problem rather than the behavior of the voters.
The reporting on the process is argued to be hurtful to the voters.
The issues are not decided by the press, their coverage of process results in issues being ignored.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption upon which the argument in the passage depends?
main_answers: There is no difference between reporting on the political process and reporting on substantive issues.
The voters are not paying enough attention to the election to be able to make informed decisions.
The candidates in the election are taking positions on substantive policy issues.
How the press reports politics determines the substantive issues in the campaign.
others.target_option: The candidates in the election are taking positions on substantive policy issues.

context: Historian: The revolutionary party has been accused of having many overambitious goals and of having caused great suffering. However, most of the party' s goals were quickly achieved and the party did not have enough power to cause the suffering the critics claim it caused. So it is clear that the party was not overambitious and caused no suffering.
question: What evidence is needed to demonstrate that the historian's argument is not flawed for not providing evidence that the revolutionary party's goals were not overambitious?
answers: Being quick and being less powerful than assumed are not mutually inconsistent states.
It only implies that they minimized suffering via being quick and thorough, but doesn't establish that there was no suffering at all.
The passage actually makes the claim that the revolutionary party's critics overestimated the party's power.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning in the historian's argument is flawed because the argument
main_answers: fails to establish that the revolutionary party caused no suffering
provides no evidence that the revolutionary party's goals were not overambitious
fails to establish that any of the revolutionary party's critics underestimated the party's power
gives mutually inconsistent responses to the two criticisms
others.target_option: provides no evidence that the revolutionary party's goals were not overambitious

context: Though ice cream is an excellent source of calcium, dairy farmers report that during the past ten years there has been a sharp decline in ice cream sales. And during the same period, sales of cheddar cheese have nearly doubled. Ttherefore, more and more people must be choosing to increase their intake of calcium by eating cheddar cheese rather than ice cream.
question: Why is the reasoning not considered to be flawed for not providing statistical evidence to back up the dairy farmers' claims?
answers: There are many reasons such why ice cream sales might drop that have nothing to do with calcium content.
Only presumes that people are eating cheese instead of ice cream to get calcium, not that it is a better source.
Sales are reported, not testimony of customers.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning above is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it
main_answers: fails to produce statistical evidence supporting the dairy farmers' claims
presumes, without providing justification, that ice cream is a better source of calcium than is cheddar cheese
fails to consider alternative explanations of the decline in sales of ice cream
relies solely on the testimony of individuals who are likely to be biased
others.target_option: fails to produce statistical evidence supporting the dairy farmers' claims

context: Letter to the editor: Recently, the city council passed an ordinance that prohibits loitering at the local shopping mall. The council' s declared goal was to eliminate overcrowding and alleviate pedestrian congestion, thereby improving the mall' s business and restoring its family-oriented image. But despite these claims, reducing overcrowding and congestion cannot be the actual goals of this measure, because even when fully implemented, the ordinance would not accomplish them.
question: Explain why the argument's reasoning is not flawed by dismissing a claim because of its source rather than because of its content.
answers: The argument mentions no conditions necessary to achieve the goal of congestion reduction, it merely claims that the goal is impossible to achieve.
The argument does not address any other potential effects of the ordinance beyond those stated to be its goal.
The argument claims that overcrowding and congestion cannot be reduced, and therefore that congestion reduction cannot be the goal of the ordinance.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the argument's reasoning?
main_answers: The argument takes for granted that something cannot be the goal of an action performed unless the action will in fact achieve that goal.
The argument takes for granted that an action that does not accomplish its stated goals will not have any beneficial effects.
The argument treats a condition that is necessary for achieving an action's stated goals as if this condition were sufficient for achieving these goals.
The argument dismisses a claim because of its source rather than because of its content.
others.target_option: The argument dismisses a claim because of its source rather than because of its content.

context: To protect certain fledgling industries, the government of country Z banned imports of the types of products those industries were starting to make. As a direct result, the cost of those products to the buyers, several export-dependent industries in Z, went up, sharply limiting the ability of those industries to compete effectively in their export markets.
question: What is the basis for inferring that those products had been cheaper to import than they were to make within country Z's fledgling industries from the passage about the products whose importation was banned?
answers: Whether or not the products were imported from the same countries that country Z's exports went to was not mentioned.
Whether or not country Z wanted to export those products or produce them only for domestic use was not mentioned.
There is no evidence that there was a foreign trade deficit.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following can be most properly inferred from the passage about the products whose importation was banned?
main_answers: Those products had become more and more expensive to import, which resulted in a foreign trade deficit just before the ban.
Those products were the ones that country Z was hoping to export in its turn, once the fledgling industries matured.
Those products had been cheaper to import than they were to make within country Z's fledgling industries.
Those products used to be imported from just those countries to which country Z's exports went.
others.target_option: Those products had been cheaper to import than they were to make within country Z's fledgling industries.

context: The Rienzi, a passenger ship, sank as a result of a hole in its hull, possibly caused by sabotage. Normally, when a holed ship sinks as rapidly as the Rienzi did, water does not enter the ship quickly enough for the ship to be fully flooded when it reaches the ocean floor. Full flooding can be achieved, however, by sabotage. Any ship that sinks deep into the ocean when not fully flooded will implode. Deep-sea photographs, taken of the sunken Rienzi where it rests on the ocean floor, reveal that the Rienzi did not implode.
question: What evidence supports the conclusion that, if the Rienzi was not sunk by sabotage, water flooded into it unusually fast?
answers: The passage does not state that implosion takes place before or after the ship reaches the ocean floor.
Nowhere in the passage are we given information concerning the construction of the ship.
Speed of sinking is not correlated with implosion anywhere in the passage.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following must be true on the basis of the information above?
main_answers: If the Rienzi was not sunk by sabotage, water flooded into it unusually fast.
The Rienzi was so strongly constructed as to resist imploding under deep-sea pressure.
If the Rienzi had sunk more slowly, it would have imploded.
If the Rienzi became fully flooded, it did so only after it reached the ocean floor.
others.target_option: If the Rienzi was not sunk by sabotage, water flooded into it unusually fast.

context: When butterfat was considered nutritious and healthful, a law was enacted requiring that manufacturers use the term "imitation butter" to indicate butter whose butterfat content had been diminished through the addition of water. Today, it is known that the high cholesterol content of butterfat makes it harmful to human health. Since the public should be encouraged to eat foods with lower rather than higher butterfat content and since the term "imitation" with its connotations of falsity deters many people from purchasing products so designated, manufacturers who wish to give reduced-butterfat butter the more appealing name of "lite butter" should be allowed to do so.
question: How does the fact that most people deterred from eating "imitation butter" because of its name choose alternatives with a lower butterfat content than this product has seriously undermine the argument?
answers: Changing the composition to contain more water should not disallow them from changing the name to lite butter.
Regardless of their motivation, they are changing to lite instead of imitation, to appeal more to customers and should be allowed to.
The fact that some individuals are not deterred, does not change the fact that many are deterred by the term.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the argument?
main_answers: Most people deterred from eating "imitation butter" because of its name choose alternatives with a lower butterfat content than this product has.
Some individuals who need to reduce their intake of cholesterol are not deterred from using the reduced-butterfat product by the negative connotations of the term "imitation. "
The manufacturers who wish to call their product "lite butter" plan to change the composition of the product so that it contains more water than it now does.
The manufacturers who prefer to use the word "lite" instead of "imitation" are motivated principally by the financial interest of their stockholders.
others.target_option: Most people deterred from eating "imitation butter" because of its name choose alternatives with a lower butterfat content than this product has.

context: Politician: The mandatory jail sentences that became law two years ago for certain crimes have enhanced the integrity of our system of justice, for no longer are there two kinds of justice, the kind dispensed by lenient judges and the kind dispensed by severe ones. Public advocate: But with judges stripped of discretionary powers, there can be no leniency even where it would be appropriate. So juries now sometimes acquit a given defendant solely because the jurors feel that the mandatory sentence would be too harsh. Those juries, then, do not return an accurate verdict on the defendant' s guilt. This is why it is imperative that the legislation instituting mandatory jail sentences be repealed.
question: What is the reason for the public advocate not responding to the politician's argument by claiming that the politician's evidence, properly analyzed, has no bearing on the conclusion the politician derives from it?
answers: Whether leniency is a property of decisions or individuals is not relevant to the advocate's main point that a lack of room for leniency is a barrier to accuracy.

The politician argues about how the legislation helped enhance the integrity of the system, while the advocate argues that the integrity of the system is harmed in another way when looking at the consequences more deeply.
The severity of any problem is not referred to by the advocate.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The public advocate responds to the politician's argument by doing which one of the following?
main_answers: arguing that leniency is not a trait of individuals but that, rather, it is a property of certain kinds of decisions
charging that the politician exaggerated the severity of a problem in order to justify a sweeping solution
claiming that the politician's evidence, properly analyzed, has no bearing on the conclusion the politician derives from it
arguing that an analysis of the consequences of certain legislation undermines the politician's conclusion
others.target_option: claiming that the politician's evidence, properly analyzed, has no bearing on the conclusion the politician derives from it

context: Meerkat "sentinels, " so-called because they watch for predators while other meerkat group members forage, almost never fall victim to those predators, yet the foragers often do. This advantage accruing to the sentinel does not mean that its watchful behavior is entirely self-interested. On the contrary, the sentinel' s behavior is an example of animal behavior motivated at least in part by altruism. The loud bark emitted by the sentinel as it dashes for the cover of the nearest hole alerts other group members to the presence of danger.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the argument employs the questionable reasoning technique of inferring solely from an effect produced by an action that a purpose of the action is to produce that effect?
answers: That watchful behavior is self-interested isn't identified as a specific claim and evidence about this is not discussed.
The author gives evidence of sentinels barking which would support their argument that there is altruism, not undermine it.
The evidence that sentinels bark does not presuppose the conclusion that there is altruism, it only supports it.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is a questionable reasoning technique employed in the argument?
main_answers: concluding that a claim is false on the grounds that insufficient evidence has been offered to support it
appealing to evidence that tends to undermine rather than support the argument's conclusion
appealing to evidence that presupposes the truth of the argument's conclusion
inferring solely from an effect produced by an action that a purpose of the action is to produce that effect
others.target_option: inferring solely from an effect produced by an action that a purpose of the action is to produce that effect

context: A newly discovered painting seems to be the work of one of two seventeenth-century artists, either the northern German Johannes Drechen or the Frenchman Louis Birelle, who sometimes painted in the same style as Drechen. Analysis of the carved picture frame, which has been identified as the painting's original seventeenth-century frame, showed that it is made of wood found widely in northern Germany at the time, but rare in the part of France where Birelle lived. This shows that the painting is most likely the work of Drechen.
question: What is the reasoning for why the argument does not require the assumption that sometimes a painting so resembles others of its era that no expert is able to confidently decide who painted it?
answers: Visiting a certain area or not does not indicate when a painting was created since materials could have been taken to other areas.
Since types of wood can be regional, a product made with a certain type would be more likely to have originated from that area.
Non specificity of a style makes it more possible that the art could be from anywhere rather than a specific area.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption that the argument requires?
main_answers: Sometimes a painting so resembles others of its era that no expert is able to confidently decide who painted it.
Drechen is unlikely to have ever visited the home region of Birelle in France.
The carving style of the picture frame is not typical of any specific region of Europe.
The frame was made from wood local to the region where the picture was painted.
others.target_option: Sometimes a painting so resembles others of its era that no expert is able to confidently decide who painted it.

context: Productivity is average output per worker per unit of time. High productivity cannot be achieved without adequate training of workers. So high productivity does not depend on having high-tech equipment.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be flawed for confusing a stated requirement for having high-tech equipment with a sufficient condition for having high-tech equipment?
answers: Correct.  The passage does not define what is adequate training so high tech equipment might be needed or required.
The passage is not about the desirability of productivity but rather what is required to train workers to be productive.
The passage does not focus on education as a necessary input to productivity, but rather high tech equipment.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument
main_answers: ignores the possibility that having high-tech equipment is required for adequate training of workers
overlooks the fact that increases in productivity may not be desirable in some circumstances
confuses a stated requirement for having high- tech equipment with a sufficient condition for having high-tech equipment
presumes without giving justification that educating workers always results in an increase in their productivity
others.target_option: confuses a stated requirement for having high- tech equipment with a sufficient condition for having high-tech equipment

context: When glass products are made from recycled glass, the resulting products can be equal in quality to glass products made from quartz sand, the usual raw material. When plastics are recycled, however, the result is inevitably a plastic of a lower grade than the plastic from which it is derived. Moreover, no applications have been found for grades of plastic that are lower than the currently lowest commercial grade.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the difference in quality between different grades of glass is not as great as that between different grades of plastic based on the statements above?
answers: The quality can be compared, but we don't have any information on cost
If recycled plastic ends up a lower grade that the original plastic, then recycling the lowest commercial grade would yield a plastic with with no commercial grade and therefore no application
Recycled glass products are of equal quality to first-run glass products
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is a conclusion that can be properly drawn from the statements above?
main_answers: Glass products made from recycled glass are less expensive than comparable products made from quartz sand.
Products cannot presently be made out of plastic recycled entirely from the currently lowest commercial grade.
It is impossible to make glass products from recycled glass that are equal in quality to the best glass products made from the usual raw material.
The difference in quality between different grades of glass is not as great as that between different grades of plastic.
others.target_option: The difference in quality between different grades of glass is not as great as that between different grades of plastic.

context: In a recent study, each member of two groups of people, Group A (composed of persons sixty-five to seventy-five years old) and Group B (composed of college students), was required to make a telephone call to a certain number at a specified time. The time when each call was initiated was recorded electronically. Group A proved far better at remembering to make a telephone call precisely at a specified time than did Group B. There were fourteen lapses in Group B but only one lapse in Group A. Clearly, at least one type of memory does not suffer as a person ages.
question: How does the fact that both groups had unrestricted access to telephones for making the required calls help in establishing that the conclusion is properly drawn?
answers: The number of people in each group being even would be a necessary condition for being able to make accurate inferences about the results.
If one group received instructions much longer before they were expected to make the calls, they may be more likely to forget to do so.
Who answered the calls does little to explain any difference in results between Group A and B.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if all of them are true, is LEAST helpful in establishing that the conclusion above is properly drawn?
main_answers: The members of the two groups received their instructions approximately the same amount of time before they were to make their telephone calls.
The same group of researchers answered the calls made by the callers in both study groups.
Both groups had unrestricted access to telephones for making the required calls.
There was the same number of people in each group.
others.target_option: Both groups had unrestricted access to telephones for making the required calls.

context: A development company has proposed building an airport near the city of Dalton. If the majority of Dalton' s residents favor the proposal, the airport will be built. However, it is unlikely that a majority of Dalton' s residents would favor the proposal, for most of them believe that the airport would create noise problems. Thus, it is unlikely that the airport will be built.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered flawed for treating a sufficient condition for the airport's being built as a necessary condition?
answers: There is no evidence that the residents would accept the noise for a boost to the economy.
The passage is about if the residents favor building a new airport or not.
It is not flawed to expect an event will not occur because it is unlikely to occur.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is flawed in that the argument
main_answers: treats a sufficient condition for the airport's being built as a necessary condition
overlooks the possibility that a new airport could benefit the local economy
fails to consider whether people living near Dalton would favor building the airport
concludes, on the basis that a certain event is unlikely to occur, that the event will not occur
others.target_option: treats a sufficient condition for the airport's being built as a necessary condition

context: The makers of Activite, a natural dietary supplement, claim that it promotes energy and mental alertness. To back up their claim, they offer a month' s supply of Activite free to new customers. Clearly, Activite must be effective, since otherwise it would not be in the company' s interest to make such an offer.
question: Why does the fact that the nutrients in Activite can all be obtained from a sufficiently varied and well-balanced diet not weaken the argument?
answers: Even if there are less expensive dietary supplements on the market that are just as effective as Activite that does not mean that Activite is not effective.
The handling fee is a source of revenue for the company whether the customer finds the product effective or not.
The natural ingredients or potential harmful side effects are not part of the argument about the free month' s supply showing that the product is effective.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?
main_answers: The makers of Activite charge a handling fee that is considerably more than what it costs them to pack and ship their product.
The mere fact that a dietary supplement contains only natural ingredients does not insure that it has no harmful side effects.
The nutrients in Activite can all be obtained from a sufficiently varied and well-balanced diet.
There are less expensive dietary supplements on the market that are just as effective as Activite.
others.target_option: The nutrients in Activite can all be obtained from a sufficiently varied and well-balanced diet.

context: Despite increasing international efforts to protect the natural habitats of endangered species of animals, the rate at which these species are becoming extinct continues to rise. It is clear that these efforts are wasted.
question: Explain why the fact that many countries do not recognize the increased economic benefit of tourism associated with preserved natural habitats does not weaken the argument.
answers: Despite a number of animals going extinct, a large number remain only through the efforts made to protect them.
The ease of preserving habitats has no bearing on the argument made in the passage.
The passage talks about internation efforts increasing.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?
main_answers: Many countries do not recognize the increased economic benefit of tourism associated with preserved natural habitats.
Species that would have become extinct have been saved due to the establishment of animal refuges.
Scientists are better able to preserve the habitats of endangered species now than ever before.
Scientists estimate that at least 2000 species become extinct every year.
others.target_option: Many countries do not recognize the increased economic benefit of tourism associated with preserved natural habitats.

context: Citizen: Each year since 1970, a new record has been set for the number of murders committed in this city. This fact points to the decreasing ability of our law enforcement system to prevent violent crime. City official: You overlook the fact that the city' s population has risen steadily since 1970. In fact, the number of murder victims per 100 people has actually fallen slightly in the city since 1970.
question: How does the fact that if the health care received by assault victims last year had been of the same quality as it was in 1970, the murder rate in the city last year would have turned out to be several times what it actually was strongly counter the city official's response?
answers: This would make the numbers the city official provided more accurate.
Fraud and murder are not comparable as crimes.
The demographics of murder victims would not change, that murder has gone down overall.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most strongly counter the city official's response?
main_answers: If the health care received by assault victims last year had been of the same quality as it was in 1970, the murder rate in the city last year would have turned out to be several times what it actually was.
The incidence of fraud has greatly increased in the city since 1970.
Murders and other violent crimes are more likely to be reported now than they were in 1970.
The rate of murders in the city since 1970 decreased according to the age group of the victim, decreasing more for younger victims.
others.target_option: If the health care received by assault victims last year had been of the same quality as it was in 1970, the murder rate in the city last year would have turned out to be several times what it actually was.

context: Industrialist: Environmentalists contend that emissions from our factory pose a health risk to those living downwind. The only testimony presented in support of this contention comes from residents of the communities surrounding the factory. But only a trained scientist can determine whether or not these emissions are dangerous, and none of the residents are scientists. Hence our factory' s emissions present no health risk.
question: What is the rationale for why the industrialist's argument is considered flawed for not presenting any testimony from scientists that the emissions are safe?
answers: The term "health risk" is used the same way through the passage.
The benefits to the community have nothing to do with the possible health risks coming from it.
Emissions from other sources in the area have nothing to do with whether the factory is a health risk.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning in the industrialist's argument is flawed because the argument
main_answers: equivocates between two different notions of the term "health risk"
presents no testimony from scientists that the emissions are safe
fails to discuss the benefits of the factory to the surrounding community
does not consider the safety of emissions from other sources in the area
others.target_option: presents no testimony from scientists that the emissions are safe

context: In Malsenia sales of classical records are soaring. The buyers responsible for this boom are quite new to classical music and were drawn to it either by classical scores from television commercials or by theme tunes introducing major sports events on television. Audiences at classical concerts, however, are continually shrinking in Malsenia. It can be concluded from this that the new Malsenian converts to classical music, having initially experienced this music as recorded music, are most comfortable with classical music as recorded music and really have no desire to hear live performances.
question: Explain why the argument does not assume that classical concerts in Malsenia are not limited to music that is readily available on recordings?
answers: The argument is concerned only with the existence of life (intelligent or otherwise) beyond the Earth, not on the existence of intelligence per se.
The passage makes no suggestion about where the classical records were recorded.
The argument is founded on the absence of evidence of ANY life, with no definition of that concept being given.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The argument assumes which one of the following?
main_answers: Classical concerts in Malsenia are not limited to music that is readily available on recordings.
The classical records available in Malsenia are, for the most part, not recordings of actual public concerts.
To sell well in Malsenia, a classical record must include at least one piece familiar from television.
The number of classical concerts performed in Malsenia has not decreased in response to smaller audiences.
others.target_option: Classical concerts in Malsenia are not limited to music that is readily available on recordings.

context: Historian: In rebuttal of my claim that West influenced Stuart, some people point out that West' s work is mentioned only once in Stuart' s diaries. But Stuart' s diaries mention several meetings with West, and Stuart' s close friend, Abella, studied under West. Furthermore, Stuart' s work often uses West' s terminology which, though now commonplace, none of Stuart' s contemporaries used.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that Stuart's contemporaries were not influenced by West based on the historian's statements?
answers: Considering the income group of the new publication would make withdrawing a financial choice.

The passage states that Stuart's diaries mention meetings with West and that his work often uses West's terminology which would support that idea that Stuart's work was not entirely free from West's influence.
If the advertisers hadn't expected the advertising to lead to increased sales, withdrawing would have been at least partly a financial consideration.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following propositions is most supported by the historian's statements, if those statements are true?
main_answers: Stuart's work was not entirely free from West's influence
Stuart's contemporaries were not influenced by West.
It is more likely that Stuart influenced West than that West influenced Stuart.
Stuart's discussions with Abella were one of the means by which West influenced Stuart.
others.target_option: Stuart's contemporaries were not influenced by West.

context: Drama critic: Audiences will enjoy Warner' s latest play, about the disintegration of a family, because of the superb acting. The chemistry between the actors could not be more intense, and Ziegler, who plays the child, captures convincingly the guilt and despair experienced as the family members grow more estranged from each other.
question: Why does the fact that generally audiences enjoy romantic comedies but find tragedies upsetting not weaken the argument?
answers: The history of the company does not affect an audience enjoying quality acting performances.
Whether the plot is similar to other works does not imply that the play less or more but rather the quality of the acting is referenced as being the factor that will cause audiences to like it.
Whether audiences find a review unreliable does not imply what the audiences own opinion will be.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Each of the following, if true, weakens the argument EXCEPT:
main_answers: The plot of the play is similar in some respects to plots of Warner's other works.
Audiences usually find drama critics' reviews unreliable.
Generally, audiences enjoy romantic comedies but find tragedies upsetting.
The company staging the play has an unbroken history of dull performances.
others.target_option: Generally, audiences enjoy romantic comedies but find tragedies upsetting.

context: Traditional hatcheries raise fish in featureless environments and subject them to dull routines, whereas new, experimental hatcheries raise fish in visually stimulating environments with varied routines. When released into the wild, fish from the experimental hatcheries are bolder than those from traditional hatcheries in exploring new environments and trying new types of food. Fish raised in the experimental hatcheries, ttherefore, are more likely to survive after their release.
question: What is the basis for not assuming that the quality of the environments into which hatchery-raised fish are released has little effect on the fish's survival rate in order to support the argument?
answers: If fish are timid in traditional hatcheries but more bold in others, this lends to them being more bold in the wild if not raised in traditional hatcheries.
The data concerns adults within an age range which is atypical of first year university students, and so has no bearing on the argument.
Data showing that individuals have undertaken the spending reduction suggested by the hypothesis have indeed seen the results predicted by it clearly strengthens the hypothesis.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: The quality of the environments into which hatchery-raised fish are released has little effect on the fish's survival rate.
Some fish raised in traditional hatcheries die because they are too timid in their foraging for food.
It is economically feasible for hatchery operators to expose fish to greater visual stimulation and to more varied routines.
Fish in the wild always live in visually stimulating environments.
others.target_option: The quality of the environments into which hatchery-raised fish are released has little effect on the fish's survival rate.

context: "This company will not be training any more pilots in the foreseeable future, since we have 400 trained pilots on our waiting list who are seeking employment. The other five major companies each have roughly the same number of trained pilots on their waiting lists, and since the projected requirement of each company is for not many more than 100 additional pilots, there will be no shortage of personnel despite the current upswing in the aviation industry. "
question: Why does the fact that in the long run pilot training will become necessary to compensate for ordinary attention not cast doubt on the accuracy of the conclusion?
answers: Since it is argued that prohibition is impossible to enforce, it follows that regulation would be preferable.
The argument asserts that prohibition cannot effectively be carried out, not that it wasn't carefully considered.
The passage states that the current upswing in the aviation industry have been taken into account.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, casts the most doubt on the accuracy of the above conclusion?
main_answers: Most of the trained pilots who are on a waiting list for a job are on the waiting lists of all the major companies.
Some of the other major companies are still training pilots but with no presumption of subsequent employment.
The quoted personnel projections take account of the current upswing in the aviation industry.
In the long run, pilot training will become necessary to compensate for ordinary attention.
others.target_option: In the long run, pilot training will become necessary to compensate for ordinary attention.

context: Critic: Works of literature often present protagonists who scorn allegiance to their society and who advocate detachment rather than civic-mindedness. However, modern literature is distinguished from the literature of earlier eras in part because it more frequently treats such protagonists sympathetically. Sympathetic treatment of such characters suggests to readers that one should be unconcerned about contributing to societal good. Thus, modern literature can damage individuals who appropriate this attitude, as well as damage society at large.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the critic's argument relies on the assumption that it is to the advantage of some individuals that they be concerned with contributing to societal good?
answers: The text doesn't speak to comparing different societies.
The article has nothing to say about individuals from earlier eras.
The article only speaks to how modern literature can damage society.  It doesn't have anything to say about earlier literature.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the critic's argument relies?
main_answers: Some individuals must believe that their society is better than most before they can become concerned with benefiting it.
Modern literature is generally not as conducive to societal good as was the literature of earlier eras.
It is to the advantage of some individuals that they be concerned with contributing to societal good.
Some individuals in earlier eras were more concerned about contributing to societal good than is any modern individual.
others.target_option: It is to the advantage of some individuals that they be concerned with contributing to societal good.

context: Book collector: The demand for out-of-print books is increasing. It has been spurred by the rise of the Internet, the search capabilities of which make it much easier to locate the out-of-print books one seeks.
question: Why does the book collector's statements not strongly support the claim that only people who have access to the Internet can locate out-of-print books?
answers: The book collector suggests that the internet makes it easier for people to find the out-of-print books they seek, suggesting the demand is not from people discovering books they didn't know about before.
The passage talks about the editor's proofreading credibility by mentioning an incident where her ability to proofread is questioned.
This example is more of a conflict of interest.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The book collector's statements, if true, most strongly support which one of the following?
main_answers: Book collectors are now using the Internet to find book titles that they previously did not know existed.
Only people who have access to the Internet can locate out-of-print books.
The amount of demand for out-of-print books is affected by the ease of finding such books.
Fewer people try to find books that are in print than try to find books that are out of print.
others.target_option: Only people who have access to the Internet can locate out-of-print books.

context: Doctor: Angiotensinogen is a protein in human blood. Typically, the higher a person' s angiotensinogen levels are, the higher that person' s blood pressure is. Disease X usually causes an increase in angiotensinogen levels. Ttherefore, disease X must be a cause of high blood pressure.
question: Why is it valid to criticize the doctor's argument on the grounds that it illicitly infers, solely on the basis of two phenomena being correlated, that one causally contributes to the other?
answers: A third phenomenon could be caused by a first phenomenon that causes a second which causes the third.
If it is a necessary condition, it would likely be a sufficient condition.
Whether or not Disease X has other factors that would fully counteract (and thus reduce) high angiotensinogen levels is not discussed, simply that it causes high angiotensinogen levels.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The doctor 's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on which one of the following grounds?
main_answers: It overlooks the possibility that even if a condition causally contributes to a given effect, other factors may fully counteract that effect in the presence of that condition.

It takes for granted that if one phenomenon often causes a second phenomenon and that second phenomenon often causes a third phenomenon, then the first phenomenon cannot ever be the immediate cause of the third.
It illicitly infers, solely on the basis of two phenomena being correlated, that one causally contributes to the other.
It confuses a necessary condition for a sufficient condition.
others.target_option: It illicitly infers, solely on the basis of two phenomena being correlated, that one causally contributes to the other.

context: Fast-food restaurants make up 45 percent of all restaurants in Cantaria. Customers at these restaurants tend to be young; in fact, studies have shown that the older people get, the less likely they are to eat in fast-food restaurants. Since the average age of the Canatrian population is gradually rising and will continue to do so, the number of fast-food restaurants is likely to decrease.
question: Explain why the fact that the population of Canatria is getting older and more people are eating at home does not seriously weaken the argument.
answers: If the mine supplied nearby riverbeds with significant quantities of gold, it reasons that there is a good chance that the artifacts in question were perhaps not dug from the mine itself but from the nearby riverbeds.
If the population is growing, even with the higher age, there will still be enough business to keep the restaurants open.
How long the mine was operated before artifacts were constructed would neither strengthen or weaken the argument and is inconsequential to whether or not the artifacts were dug from the ancient mine.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: As the population of Canatria gets older, more people are eating at home.
The overall population of Canatria is growing steadily.
Fast-food restaurants in Canatria are getting bigger, so each one can serve more customers.
Many people who rarely eat in fast-food restaurants nevertheless eat regularly in restaurants.
others.target_option: As the population of Canatria gets older, more people are eating at home.

context: Environment minister: Many countries have signed an international agreement that is intended to reduce pollution in the world' s oceans. While conformity to this agreement probably would significantly reduce pollution in the world' s oceans, it would also probably reduce economic growth in our country and others. Ttherefore, our country should not sign the agreement.
question: Why does the fact that a policy is likely to protect the environment and is unlikely to reduce economic growth not help to justify the environment minister's argument?
answers: Whether or not the goal of reducing pollution in the world's oceans can be achieved is not called into question.
The rings are set that way no matter the age of the pig. On older pig would have more rings, but the type of ring at the top at the time of death does not indicate age.
The normal ring growth is 3 months in the summer and 3 months in the winter. If there winter growth is only half done, there would only be half the width of the ring.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, would most help to justify the environment minister's argument?
main_answers: A country should not sign an agreement that is unlikely to achieve its stated goal.
If a policy is likely to protect the environment and is unlikely to reduce economic growth, then governments should implement that policy.
When deciding whether to sign an agreement, a country should consider the agreement's effects on other countries' economies as well as on its own economy.
It is more important to maintain economic growth in one's own country than it is to reduce pollution in the world's oceans.
others.target_option: If a policy is likely to protect the environment and is unlikely to reduce economic growth, then governments should implement that policy.

context: Forty to 60 percent of students report, in anonymous surveys, that they plagiarized at least once as undergraduates, and evidence indicates that plagiarism also occurs in our medical and business schools. Researchers have found that students who plagiarize are more likely to engage in subsequent professional misconduct such as falsified research results and fraudulent business practices. Thus, a reduction of academic plagiarism will lead to a reduction of professional misconduct.
question: Explain why the argument does not have a flaw as accurately described by the fact that it presumes, without providing justification, that a certain phenomenon is the only factor contributing to the incidence of a certain other phenomenon?
answers: The brain making less dopamine in those with Parkinson's supports the idea that the lack of dopamine causes the medical issue.
Professional misconduct can be performed by people who did not plagiarize as an undergraduate.
Other chemicals affecting the brain does not reduce the possibility that dopamine causes Parkinson's.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the reasoning in the argument?
main_answers: The argument presumes, without providing justification, that a certain phenomenon is the only factor contributing to the incidence of a certain other phenomenon.
The argument infers the existence of a causal connection merely on the basis of an association.
The argument takes for granted that a certain behavior is more prevalent among members of one population than it is among members of another.
The argument introduces one subject for debate, but proceeds to give premises relevant to a different subject.
others.target_option: The argument presumes, without providing justification, that a certain phenomenon is the only factor contributing to the incidence of a certain other phenomenon.

context: In an experiment, researchers played a series of musical intervals -- two-note sequences -- to a large, diverse group of six-month-old babies. They found that the babies paid significantly more attention when the intervals were perfect octaves, fifths, or fourths than otherwise. These intervals are prevalent in the musical systems of most cultures around the world. Thus, humans probably have a biological predisposition to pay more attention to those intervals than to others.
question: Explain why the fact that octaves, fifths, and fourths were played more frequently during the experiment than other musical intervals were does not strengthen the argument.
answers: This strengthens the argument because without this requirement environmental causation cannot be ruled out.
Such exposure to the environment of world music, which mostly favors two-note intervals, makes the biological predisposition argument invalid.
It is impossible to rule out the cultural or environmental influence in older children and adults.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_answers: Octaves, fifths, and fourths were played more frequently during the experiment than other musical intervals were.

Several similar experiments using older children and adults found that these subjects, too, had a general tendency to pay more attention to octaves, fifths, and fourths than to other musical intervals.
All of the babies in the experiment had been exposed to music drawn equally from a wide variety of cultures around the world.
None of the babies in the experiment had previous exposure to music from any culture.
others.target_option: Octaves, fifths, and fourths were played more frequently during the experiment than other musical intervals were.

context: A hardware store generally sells roughly equal numbers of Maxlast brand hammers and Styron brand hammers. Last week, all of the Maxlast hammers were put on sale and placed in a display case just inside the store entrance while the Styron hammers retained their usual price and location. Surprisingly, the Styron hammers slightly outsold the Maxlast hammers.
question: What is the reason for the surprising result not being explained by the fact that customers who bought the Maxlast hammers last week commonly mentioned the sale as their reason for buying a hammer at that time?
answers: If the Maxlast hammers were being promoted in flyers, one would expect them to be more popular than the Styron hammers which weren't promoted.
One would expect that the customers would walk right by the Maxlast hammers as they immediately entered the store and not see the promotional display.
One would still expect those shoppers that were in the store already to buy the cheaper hammer.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, does most to explain the surprising result?
main_answers: Customers who bought the Maxlast hammers last week commonly mentioned the sale as their reason for buying a hammer at that time.
The hardware store circulated flyers that publicized the sale prices on Maxlast hammers.
For the first several seconds after shoppers enter a store, they do not take detailed notice of the store's merchandise.
In general, a single item that is on sale will not motivate shoppers to make a special trip to a store.
others.target_option: Customers who bought the Maxlast hammers last week commonly mentioned the sale as their reason for buying a hammer at that time.

context: Although most people know what their bad habits are and want to rid themselves of them, a majority of these people find it very difficult to do so. This is because cessation of habitual behavior is immediately and vividly painful, while whatever benefit is to be gained by the absence of the habit is perceived only dimly because it is remote.
question: What evidence supports the statement that the people who are successful at ending their bad habits are those who can vividly imagine remote but attainable benefit?
answers: Imagining the current pain continuing into the future is defeatism, which is the opposite of motivation.
Someone who is unaware of their own bad habits is not likely to want to change them.
Modifying behavior is not quite the same as completely ending a bad behavioral characteristic.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The information above most strongly supports the statement that the people who are most successful at ending their bad habits are those who
main_answers: have succeeded in the past at modifying their behavior
can vividly imagine remote but attainable benefit
can vividly imagine their present pain being felt in the future
are relatively unaware of their own behavioral characteristics
others.target_option: can vividly imagine remote but attainable benefit

context: Statistics from the National Booksellers Association indicate that during the last five years most bookstores have started to experience declining revenues from the sale of fiction, despite national campaigns to encourage people to read more fiction. Ttherefore, these reading campaigns have been largely unsuccessful.
question: Explain why the fact that due to the poor economic conditions that have prevailed during the last five years, most libraries report substantial increases in the number of patrons seeking books on changing careers and starting new businesses does not weaken the argument?
answers: The substantial growth in mail order fiction sales could be more than the decline in bookstore sales, thus the campaign would not be unsuccessful.
Understanding the methods has no bearing on which methods works best.
The variability of the plants is not addressed but rather the viability.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: The National Booksellers Association statistics do not include profits from selling novels by mail to overseas customers.
During the last five years the most profitable items in bookstores have been newspapers and periodicals rather than novels.

Due to the poor economic conditions that have prevailed during the last five years, most libraries report substantial increases in the number of patrons seeking books on changing careers and starting new businesses.
Mail order book clubs have enjoyed substantial growth in fiction sales throughout the last five years.
others.target_option: Due to the poor economic conditions that have prevailed during the last five years, most libraries report substantial increases in the number of patrons seeking books on changing careers and starting new businesses.

context: People should avoid taking the antacid calcium carbonate in doses larger than half a gram, for despite its capacity to neutralize stomach acids, calcium carbonate can increase the calcium level in the blood and thus impair kidney function. Moreover, just half a gram of it can stimulate the production of gastrin, a stomach hormone that triggers acid secretion.
question: Why is it not reasonable to conclude that people who avoid taking more than half a gram of calcium carbonate are less likely than average to suffer from impaired kidney function based on the information provided?
answers: The antacid reduces stomach acid in general and there is no mention of how effective each dose is at neutralizing acid.
That cannot be inferred from the passage because there could theoretically be many other forms of depression that can be treated more easily than baking and eating cookies.

That cannot be properly inferred because the passage only talks about increasing the level of serotonin in the brain. Lack of sunlight may leave the brain at a base level of serotonin rather than lower it.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_answers: Half a gram of calcium carbonate can causally contribute to both the secretion and the neutralization of stomach acids.
Impaired kidney function may increase the level of calcium in the blood.
People who avoid taking more than half a gram of calcium carbonate are less likely than average to suffer from impaired kidney function.
Doses of calcium carbonate smaller than half a gram can reduce stomach acid more effectively than much larger doses do.
others.target_option: People who avoid taking more than half a gram of calcium carbonate are less likely than average to suffer from impaired kidney function.

context: During its caterpillar stage, the leopard magpie moth feeds on a plant called the Natal grass cycad and by so doing laces its body with macrozamin, a toxin that makes the moth highly unpalatable to would-be predators. Since the Natal grass cycad is now endangered and facing extinction, the leopard magpie moth is also in danger of extinction.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument does not require the assumption that the leopard magpie moth does not have the speed or the agility to escape from any of its potential predators?
answers: Since potential predators find the leopard magpie moth unpalatable, they are not able to consume them and build a tolerance.
If  the leopard magpie moth had other means of making itself unpalatable, there'd be no relation between either going extinct.
Potential predators find macrozamin unpalatable whether they can see it or not.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Potential predators of the leopard magpie moth cannot determine from appearance alone whether a moth's body is laced with macrozamin.
The leopard magpie moth does not have the speed or the agility to escape from any of its potential predators.
None of the potential predators of the leopard magpie moth have developed a tolerance to macrozamin.
Feeding on the Natal grass cycad is the only means by which the leopard magpie moth can make itself highly unpalatable to predators.
others.target_option: The leopard magpie moth does not have the speed or the agility to escape from any of its potential predators.

context: Despite the best efforts of astronomers, no one has yet succeeded in exchanging messages with intelligent life on other planets or in other solar systems. In fact, no one has even managed to prove that any kind of extraterrestrial life exists. Thus, there is clearly no intelligent life anywhere but on Earth.
question: Why is the argument's reasoning considered flawed for confusing an absence of evidence for a hypothesis with the existence of evidence against the hypothesis?
answers: The author is focusing solely on mathematics and how that can help keep a competitive edge in the global economy.
The author does not statet hat this will guarantee that it will be overcome but that it will make help make it possible.
No analogy of any kind is made during the argument.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The argument's reasoning is flawed because the argument
main_answers: relies on a weak analogy rather than on evidence to draw a conclusion
confuses an absence of evidence for a hypothesis with the existence of evidence against the hypothesis
makes an inference that relies on the vagueness of the term "life"
fails to consider that there might be extraterrestrial forms of intelligence that are not living beings
others.target_option: confuses an absence of evidence for a hypothesis with the existence of evidence against the hypothesis

context: Advertisement for a lactase supplement: Lactase, an enzyme produced by the body, aids in the digestion of lactose, a natural sugar found in dairy foods. Many subjects in an experiment who drank a liter of milk on an empty stomach showed signs of lactose intolerance -- difficulty in digesting dairy products because of insufficient lactase. Thus, extrapolating from the number of subjects adversely affected, at least 50 million people in North America alone should take lactase supplements.
question: Explain why the fact that some dairy foods, such as cheese, contain a form of lactose more difficult to digest than that found in milk does not seriously weaken the argument.
answers: If jokes do not conform to patterns but rather break them, then they would be more difficult to remember as the brains remembers best with repeated patterns.
